? Baterias de ensaios
Os ensaios foram divididos em três baterias. Na primeira bateria, foram realizados
ensaios em solo arenoso e argiloso, e buscou-se a validação da metodologia proposta para a
tese, a verificação do procedimento de cravação, com jatos de água circulares verticais únicos
e contínuos, como também o entendimento dos parâmetros que influenciam na cravação dos
modelos, tais como: vazão e velocidade do jato de água, diâmetro e massa da haste utilizada
para simular a estaca torpedo, variação da posição de início dos jatos de água, e propriedades
do leito de solo a ser fluidizado. Tais ensaios em modelo compreenderam a utilização de três
vazões para o solo arenoso (0,7; 1,0 e 1,6 L/min) e duas vazões para o solo argiloso
(4,2 e 7,0 L/min), dois diâmetros externos de modelo (14,0 e 16,2 mm), duas massas para
cada modelo, e duas profundidades de início dos ensaios (superfície e pré-instalada).
Trabalhou-se com o solo arenoso compactado com 50% de densidade relativa.
Através da primeira bateria de ensaios, constatou-se que a cravação em solo argiloso,
por peso próprio associado à remoção de massa de solo através de jatos verticais únicos e
contínuos a partir da superfície, não foi viável com esta metodologia adotada. O sistema de

jateamento mostrou-se ineficaz, pois o solo adere fortemente ao fuste das hastes ocasionado
sucessivas rupturas hidráulicas no leito, pelas quais o fluxo de água atinge a superfície. Para
solo arenoso, esta metodologia de cravação revelou-se satisfatória quando o processo de
fluidização ocorre desde a superfície do solo. Já os ensaios realizados com hastes pré-
instaladas, isto é, com as hastes cravadas a certa profundidade, ocorreram sem sucesso, pois
não houve acréscimo na cravação das hastes com a ligação do fluxo de água. O processo de
fluidização não desenvolveu energia suficiente para abrir uma cavidade com material
fluidizado no entorno do fuste, partindo da ponta da estaca à superfície do solo. A fluidização
permaneceu localizada na ponta do modelo, próximo ao orifício de saída do jato. A formação
de uma zona fluidizada conectada com a superfície, relatada no Capítulo 3, mostrou-se
fundamental para ocorrer a instalação dos modelos. Portanto, concluiu-se que era essencial
iniciar o processo de jateamento desde a superfície do solo arenoso para obterem-se resultados
satisfatórios.
Visto que os ensaios realizados em solo arenoso foram bem sucedidos, o foco da tese
concentrou-se neste material. Nas baterias seguintes, foram realizados ensaios em solo
arenoso, com as hastes posicionadas na superfície do leito. Buscou-se o aumento do banco de
dados, com a realização de novos ensaios de penetração por fluidização, e a comprovação do
comportamento com a repetição de ensaios de penetração por fluidização já realizados na
bateria anterior. Também foram realizados ensaios de arrancamento axial e ensaios de
comportamento geométrico da zona fluidizada.
Na segunda bateria foi acrescida mais uma vazão (2,2 L/min), resultando em quatro
vazões, mantendo-se os dois diâmetros externos de hastes e duas massas de haste para cada
diâmetro. Nesta bateria foram realizados ensaios de arrancamento axial em hastes cravadas
em solo (i) fluidizado e (ii) não fluidizado, imediatamente e 24 horas após cravação.
Trabalhou-se com o solo arenoso compactado na densidade relativa de 50%. Os ensaios de
arrancamento em solos fluidizados foram executados na continuação dos ensaios de instalação
por fluidização, ou seja, as mesmas hastes instaladas eram arrancadas.
Na terceira bateria, foi acrescido um diâmetro externo de haste (21,3 mm), totalizando
três diâmetros de modelo e seis massas (duas massas para cada diâmetro de haste), quatro
vazões e solo arenoso compactado na densidade relativa de 50% e 90%. Nesta bateria, os
ensaios de arrancamento axial ocorreram imediatamente, 4, 24 e 48 horas após a instalação
das hastes em solo fluidizado, e imediatamente e 24 horas após a cravação das hastes em solo
não fluidizado. Mais uma vez, os ensaios de arrancamento em solos fluidizados foram
executados na continuação dos ensaios de instalação por fluidização. Os ensaios na lateral do

zona perturbada no solo arenoso compactado em duas densidades relativas (50% e 90%), com
a aplicação de três vazões (0,7; 1,0 e 1,6 L/min) e empregando os três diâmetros externos de
modelos, sendo uma massa para cada diâmetro (totalizado 3 massas).
? Número de ensaios
Em solo argiloso foi realizado um ensaio central de jateamento por tanque. Já em solo
arenoso foram realizados ensaios de instalação e arrancamento axial, com e sem fluidização,
sendo executados de um a cinco ensaios por tanque, iniciando-se pelos centrais, otimizando os
trabalhos, com excelente repetibilidade e, três ensaios de geometria por face do tanque,
iniciando-se pelos ensaios centrais, seguidos de dois ensaios laterais for face, totalizando doze
ensaios por tanque, apresentando ótima reprodutibilidade. Os ensaios de cravação por apenas
peso próprio sem fluidização ou jateamento precederam os demais ensaios, fazendo uso dos
mesmos tanques, visto que a profundidade atingida era muito pequena e a perturbação do solo
no tanque era pontual e irrelevante para a causar danos às amostras.

Capítulo 5 – APRESENTAÇÃO E
ANÁLISE DOS RESULTADOS
5.1 Considerações iniciais
Este capítulo destina-se a apresentação e análise dos resultados dos ensaios de
laboratório realizados nesta pesquisa de doutorado. Inicia-se pelos resultados dos ensaios em
areia, com a análise dos mecanismos e geometria, comportamento e profundidades atingidas
pelos modelos por fluidização. Juntamente com os resultados de fluidização são apresentados
os resultados de profundidade de cravação sem fluidização. Na sequência são apresentados e
analisados os resultados de capacidade de carga dos modelos de estaca em solo fluidizado e
não fluidizado. Por fim, são apresentados os resultados e as conclusões referentes aos ensaios
em argila, quanto às profundidades cravadas com e sem jateamento.
5.2 Resultados dos ensaios em solo arenoso
5.2.1 Mecanismos e geometria da zona fluidizada
Com relação aos mecanismos e a geometria, o processo de instalação de estacas
modelo por jateamento, devido à combinação da ação de suas massas com a fluidização do
solo, possuiu semelhanças em relação aos estudos de hastes suspensas apresentados no
Capítulo 3. Três zonas distintas foram observadas: (i) zona superior, localizada na superfície
do solo em torno do fuste da estaca, onde a areia expelida é depositada com a formação de
uma duna; (ii) zona intermediária, a qual conecta a ponta da estaca modelo com a superfície
do solo, localizada ao longo do fuste da estaca, com a formação de uma cavidade erodida bem
definida, por onde o fluxo de água carrega os grãos de areia em um estado liquefeito para a
superfície, e lubrifica a área superficial da estaca reduzindo o atrito superficial do contato
solo/estaca a quase zero, auxiliando no movimento descendente de penetração do modelo para
o interior do leito arenoso; (iii) zona inferior, localizada na ponta do modelo, onde a estrutura
da areia é destruída nas imediações do orifício de saída do jato, apresentando baixa
resistência, resultando em um líquido pesado formado por uma mistura de areia e água que
escapa para a superfície ao longo do fuste da estaca, facilitando a sua cravação.

A Figura 5.1 apresenta um desenho esquemático da geometria da zona fluidizada em
hastes suspensas e instaladas por peso próprio.
Figura 5.1 – Geometria da zona fluidizada por tubos (a) suspensos e (b) peso próprio.
Os ensaios de instalação por peso próprio com fluidização contínua obedecem aos
mesmos princípios que os ensaios de instalação com tubos suspensos (condição controlada).
A principal diferença entre o modo de instalação dos modelos por peso próprio em relação a
um tubo de suspenso é que este último ocorre através de incrementos constantes de
profundidade no leito arenoso fluidizado, conforme descrito no Capítulo 3. Durante a
instalação dos modelos de estaca por peso próprio associado à fluidização do solo, a energia
requerida para remover o solo abaixo da ponta da estaca mostrou-se inferior a energia
necessária para criar uma cavidade fluidizada e mantê-la ao longo do fuste da estaca. Por
consequência disto, o volume de solo fluidizado no entorno do fuste apresentou-se inferior
quando comparado com tubos suspensos. As dimensões dH (diâmetro da zona fluidizada) e a
(alcance do jato) foram aproximadamente constantes durante a penetração dos modelos, sendo
dH formado por uma pequena zona de areia fluidizada próxima e paralela ao diâmetro da
estaca e a praticamente zero durante todos os momentos da penetração por peso próprio. Esta
geometria foi produzida devido à maior velocidade de instalação dos modelos no solo, não
permitindo tempo suficiente para o alargamento da cavidade fluidizada no entorno da estaca
em comparação com tubos suspensos. Com a interrupção da penetração e mantendo o fluxo
de água, observou-se o alargamento da zona fluidizada dH a partir da ponta do modelo para a
superfície, sendo uma condição similar a um tubo suspenso.

Figura 5.8 – Zona fluidizada medida dH versus prevista dH0 para ensaios na lateral do tanque (Dr = 50% e 90%).
Diferentemente do esperado, o valor calculado de dH0 não é maior que o real
(medido) dH. Acredita-se que nos ensaios de fluidização do solo uma parcela da vazão
aplicada percola radialmente atingindo a zona não fluidizada (fluxo Darciano), no entorno da
zona perturbada, onde se concentra a vazão responsável pela fluidização. A equação para
estimativa de dH0 sugere o aumento da zona fluidizada com o aumento da vazão aplicada, o
que não foi observado nos ensaios de fluidização por peso próprio, sendo aceitável, visto que
se trata de uma equação teórica.
A importância de conhecer o diâmetro da zona perturbada (dH) abrange desde questões
ambientais e estruturais com relação a sua vizinhança, quando se emprega a fluidização em
estacas onshore, conforme abordado no Capítulo 3, como também quando aplicados
carregamentos inclinados, no caso específico de estacas torpedo offshore, pois maior é a área
de massa de solo no entorno da estaca a ser mobilizada durante a ocorrência dos esforços de
tração. Assim, tendo um solo fluidizado de espessura aproximadamente 2de no entorno da
estaca e a este um solo não perturbado, pode-se estimar sua capacidade de carga sabendo o
comportamento e a zona de abrangência de tais solos.
5.2.2 Comportamento durante a instalação por fluidização
Constatou-se que a instalação da estaca por fluidização é um processo contínuo, no
qual a taxa de penetração decresce gradualmente com a profundidade. A combinação de
modelos de estacas pesadas com vazões baixas levou a uma ligeira mudança no
Capítulo 5 – Apresentação e Análise dos Resultados
Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015
120
comportamento de penetração observado, levando a descontinuidade do processo de
instalação.
Durante a penetração dita como descontínua, no início da instalação por fluidização, a
penetração foi temporariamente interrompida devido à obstrução do orifício de saída do jato,
assim, a vazão (Q0), a velocidade do jato (U0) e a velocidade de instalação (v) reduziram
momentaneamente. Consequentemente, a pressão (P0) em um ponto fixo à montante da saída
do jato aumentou para restabelecer o escoamento e reabrir a cavidade obstruída. Uma vez que
o orifício não estava mais obstruído, a pressão, a vazão e a velocidade do jato retornaram aos
seus valores de equilíbrio originais e a velocidade de instalação retomou o seu comportamento
inicial.

penetração constante e descontínua, e o comportamento dos parâmentos controlados durante
estes dois tipos de penetração observados.

5.2.4 Comparação dos resultados com pesquisas anteriores de fluidização
As profundidades atingidas dos modelos através da fluidização do solo arenoso fino
foram comparadas com os resultados de profundidade crítica (T3) encontradas por Niven
(1998) e Stracke (2012), em seus estudos de fluidização com haste suspensa no centro do
tanque, em leito arenoso fino (Figuras 5.23a,b). Verificou-se que os resultados foram
próximos e apresentaram tendência de aumento da profundidade atingida (L, T3) com o
aumento da vazão (Q0) aplicada. Os resultados, desta pesquisa, apresentam influência da
massa ao ar do modelo (conforme relatado nos itens 5.2.2 e 5.2.3) diferentemente dos ensaios
idealizados com haste suspensa, onde a massa dos modelos não intervém na profundidade
crítica de fluidização. Assim, percebe-se graficamente que a amplitude da profundidade
atingida é maior para uma mesma vazão aplicada. A Figura 5.23c apresenta os resultados de
areia fina da presente pesquisa juntamente com outras granulometrias de areias referentes às
pesquisas de Niven (1998) e Stracke (2012).
A profundidade crítica (T3) refere-se ao fechamento da cavidade fluidizada. O solo
arenoso localizado ao logo do fuste dos tubos suspensos inseridos no leito não se encontra
mais em suspensão. A fluidização ocorre apenas no entorno do orifício de saída do jato (ponta
do tubo), com predominância de fluxo radial (Shepley & Bolton, 2014). Conforme relatado
nesta pesquisa, para ocorrer a instalação dos modelos é essencial que toda areia no entorno do
fuste encontre-se fluidizada, pois quando a fluidização está limitada a região da ponta da
estaca, a mesma não penetra por peso próprio. Desta forma, verifica-se que as profundidades
T3 e L estão correlacionadas, sendo que a profundidade final (L) atingida pelos modelos
instalados por peso próprio através da fluidização é função da profundidade crítica de
fluidização (T3), como também da vazão aplicada (Q0).

Figura 5.24 – Capacidade de carga em solo não fluidizado na (a) Dr = 50% e (b) Dr = 90%.
As cargas foram aplicadas em pequenos incrementos e foram mantidas por alguns
minutos necessários para a estabilização das leituras dos sensores. Somente a carga final,
referente a grandes deslocamentos, foi tomada como a capacidade de carga (Qf), sendo a carga
correspondente ao peso do modelo já desconsiderada.
Os valores de Qf medidos a partir dos testes realizados imediatamente (0h) após a
cravação permaneceram praticamente os mesmos dos testes realizados 24 horas após a
cravação. Esta constatação reflete os baixos níveis de tensão de confinamento (1G) aplicadas
nos ensaios, sendo corroborada pela revisão da literatura apresentada no Capítulo 2, onde os
efeitos de ganho de resistência no tempo (setup) em laboratório não são acentuados, o efeito
de quebra dos grãos (crushing) é minimizado e a dissipação das poropressões ocorre
rapidamente.
Os resultados de Qf mostraram ser dependentes do comprimento instalado da estaca
modelo (L) e da densidade relativa de compactação da areia (Dr), com um aumento de
capacidade de carga de 55% com o aumento da densidade relativa de 50% para 90%. Além
disso, os resultados mostraram a influência do diâmetro (de) dos modelos de estaca. Quanto
maior a densidade relativa do solo (Dr), o comprimento cravado (L) e o diâmetro (de) da
estaca, maior é a carga última de resistência lateral (Qf) observada. Conclusões similares
foram relatadas em Alawneh et al. (1999) em relação ao aumento de Qf com o aumento da
densidade relativa (Dr) e em Shanker et al. (2007) com relação ao aumento da capacidade de
carga (Qf) com o aumento da relação L/de.
Durante a cravação das estacas foi observado o embuchamento (plug) das mesmas, em
torno de 30 mm, logo no início do processo de instalação, para os três diâmetros de hastes

Analisando o tempo entre a instalação e o arrancamento dos modelos desta pesquisa,
concluiu-se que os resultados dos ensaios de arrancamento em solo fluidizado 24 e 48 horas
após a instalação dos modelos foram similares entre si, sendo ambos em torno de 47%

em comparação a estacas instaladas em areia não fluidizada. Além disso, ao final do processo
de instalação dos modelos por fluidização, observou-se o fechamento da cavidade com a
deposição dos grãos em suspensão, conforme relatado no Capítulo 3 e no item 5.2.1. Assim, a
redistribuição e reacomodação dos grãos e a dissipação das poropressões geradas apresentam-
se como mecanismos, em potencial, responsáveis pelos efeitos de setup observados.

Após fluidizado, o solo apresenta densidade relativa em torno de 30%, próximo ao seu
estado crítico, independentemente da densidade relativa de compactação a qual a amostra foi
preparada, sendo de 50% e 90%. Tal constatação é relevante para o fenômeno de fluidização
modelado sob condições de instalação por fluidização em campo, como é almejado, pois esta
ocorrência não é afetada por efeito de escala, apesar da substancial diferença entre as tensões
de confinamento, as quais existem entre os testes no laboratório e os testes em campo.
A zona perturbada pela fluidização durante a instalação das estacas diminui a
densidade relativa no entorno do eixo do fuste das mesmas, reduzindo a capacidade de carga
axial à tração. Os resultados de Qf ao arrancamento axial mostraram ser dependentes do
comprimento instalado da estaca modelo (L) e da densidade relativa da areia (Dr) no entorno
da mesma. Quanto maior a densidade relativa do solo (Dr), o comprimento cravado (L) e o
diâmetro (de) da estaca, maior é a carga última de resistência lateral (Qf) observada.
Os coeficients de empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) foram calculados a partir das cargas
de ruptura ao arrancamento axial (Qf) e mostraram-se maiores quanto maior da densidade
relativa (Dr) e menores as tensões de confinamento (?'vo).
Os valores de Ks obtidos em solo não fluidizado, para as maiores tensões de
confinamento (L = 500 mm), mostraram-se relativamente constantes, correspondendo a
aproximadamente 0,40 para Dr = 50% e 0,60 para Dr = 90%. Já em solo fluidizado
(Dr ? 30%), os valores de Ks obtidos foram de aproximadamente 0,10 (0h e 4h) e 0,15
(24h e 48h), sendo relativamente constantes para as maiores tensões de confinamento
(L ? 800 mm).
Não foi observado ganho de resistência no tempo para as estacas ensaiadas à tração
axial em solo não fluidizado, para testes realizados imediatamente (0h) e 24h após a cravação.
Em contra partida, as estacas ensaiadas à tração axial em solo fluidizado apresentaram ganho
de capacidade de carga com tempo de 24 horas após a instalação (efeito de setup). O processo
de ganho de resistência foi relacionado com a dissipação das poropressões geradas pelo
jateamento e o rearranjo/reacomodação dos grãos na cavidade perturbada/erodida no entorno
do fuste da estaca após o término da fluidização.

5.3.3 Conclusões relacionadas aos ensaios em leito argiloso
A metodologia de instalação proposta, através da aplicação de jatos de água, verticais
circulares únicos e contínuos, não foi adequada, dentro da faixa de vazões (Q0) e de
velocidades (U0) de saída do jato aplicada. As profundidades de cravação por peso próprio
com e sem a utilização de jatos foram próximas, sendo assim, apenas a massa dos modelos
governou o processo de cravação. Os jatos verticais circulares únicos e contínuos causaram
rupturas hidráulicas no leito argiloso e não removeram massa de solo por erosão. O material
argiloso aderiu-se no fuste dos modelos, não permitindo a percolação da água e o arraste de
massa de solo por esta interface. Assim, sugere-se para pesquisas futuras em leito argiloso,
(i) a aplicação de jatos em diferentes direções, partindo da ponteira e do fuste da estaca,
(ii) o aumento da faixa de velocidades (U0) de saída do jato utilizadas, uma vez que a
velocidades dos jatos regem o processo em argilas, conforme relatado no Capítulo 3, além do
(iii) o controle da velocidade de instalação, constituindo-se uma metodologia intermediária
entre o uso de tubos suspensas (Jung 2012) e por peso próprio (presente pesquisa).
5.4 Considerações finais
A partir da apresentação e análise dos resultados dos ensaios de laboratório em modelo
reduzido em solo arenoso fino, realizados nesta pesquisa de doutorado, é possível prosseguir
para as conclusões deste trabalho, o qual teve como objetivo o estudo da geometria e da
instalação por peso próprio de modelos com uso de jatos verticais circulares, e da capacidade
de carga axial à tração de estacas instaladas em solos fluidizado e não fluidizado.
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões
Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015
152
Capítulo 6 – CONCLUSÕES
6.1 Considerações iniciais
Este capítulo apresenta as conclusões desta tese de doutorado, baseadas no programa
experimental fundamentado em estudos relatados na literatura sobre fundações profundas e
jateamento de solos, e na análise dos resultados dos ensaios laboratório em modelo reduzido
(1G), de geometria, instalação e arrancamento axial, de estacas torpedo, sem aletas, em solo
arenoso fino fluidizado e não fluidizado. Inicia-se pela conclusão geral, seguindo para as
conclusões específicas relacionadas aos ensaios realizados em leito arenoso. Por fim, são
apresentadas sugestões para pesquisas futuras.
6.2 Conclusão geral
O programa experimental executado atingiu os objetivos propostos na pesquisa, o qual
almejou o estudo dos mecanismos e do comportamento de modelos instalados através da
fluidização do solo, e suas respectivas capacidades de carga axial à tração. As grandezas das
escalas de comprimento adotadas para os ensaios, em modelo reduzido, foram adequadas,
propiciando um trabalho de laboratório satisfatório.
6.3 Conclusões específicas
A metodologia de instalação proposta, através do emprego de jatos de água verticais
circulares, quando aplicados desde a superfície do leito, foi adequada, possibilitando a
cravação da estaca no solo, segundo mecanismos identificados e controlados. Tais
mecanismos, constatados a partir de ensaios com haste suspensa, foram úteis ao entendimento
dos processos de instalação de estacas torpedo por fluidização do solo.
As profundidades de instalação atingidas por fluidização do leito arenoso fino
(L/de > 50) foram superiores às profundidades cravadas pela ação do peso próprio sem
fluidização (L/de <5), indicando a vantagem do uso de jateamento de água em solos arenosos.
As profundidades de instalação atingidas no modelo, por fluidização do solo arenoso fino, são
próximas aos resultados de profundidade crítica (T3) encontrados por Niven (1998) e Stracke
(2012), em seus ensaios de fluidização de leito arenoso fino com o uso de haste suspensa.
153 Capítulo 6 – Conclusões
Instalação e Capacidade de Carga Axial de Estacas Modelo Fluidizadas em Solos Arenosos
A geometria da zona fluidizada durante a instalação dos modelos de estaca
permaneceu constante e paralela ao fuste (dH ? 2de), independentemente da vazão aplicada e
da densidade relativa inicial do solo. Ao final da instalação dos modelos, a geometria da zona
fluidizada se amplia gradativamente (dH ? 6de), sendo maior quanto maior a vazão aplicada,
assumindo o mesmo comportamento da fluidização por tubos suspensos.
A velocidade de saída do jato (U0), o diâmetro interno (di), o qual é o mesmo diâmetro
do jato (dj), e consequentemente a vazão (Q0), são parâmetros importantes no processo de
penetração por fluidização do solo arenoso, e estão todos diretamente relacionados. A vazão
(Q0) controla o processo de fluidização em areias, conforme as constatações da literatura
apresentadas no Capítulo 3.
Quando maior a massa (m) do modelo, maior a profundidade de instalação (L) atingida
para uma mesma vazão (Q0) aplicada e, quanto maior a vazão (Q0) imposta, para uma mesma
massa (m) de modelo, maior a profundidade de instalação (L) atingida. Ambas as situações
considerando o solo arenoso compactado em uma mesma densidade relativa (Dr).
O aumento da densidade relativa (Dr) diminui a profundidade instalada (L), para um
modelo de mesma massa (m) de estaca e vazão (Q0) de jateamento.
As curvas de instalação no tempo, através da fluidização do leito arenoso, mostraram
que a velocidade de penetração é inicialmente alta, associada à atuação do peso próprio. Em
seguida, a velocidade de cravação decresce de forma gradual até o momento em que modelo
para de cravar. Para ensaios dentro da mesma escala, considerando uma mesma vazão (Q0) e
densidade relativa do solo: quanto maior a massa (m), maior a velocidade inicial de instalação
(v), maior é a profundidade atingida e menor o tempo (t) para penetrar uma mesma
profundidade.
Seguindo as leis de análise dimensional, uma expressão para a penetração dos modelos
de estaca foi apresentada, a qual leva em consideração as características físicas da estaca
(massa e diâmetro), as características físicas da areia (densidade relativa inicial e diâmetro do
grão), o caudal de fluidização e as características do fluido (coeficiente de viscosidade
cinemática da água).
A análise da capacidade de carga axial à tração, dos modelos instalados em solo
fluidizado e não fluidizado, evidenciou a influência das condições de compactação do solo
(densidade relativa da areia) e do modo de instalação das estacas, tais como cravação
monotônica e por fluidização. A capacidade de carga axial à tração dos modelos mostrou-se
independente da vazão imposta durante a instalação dos modelos por fluidização.
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões
Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015
154
Constatou-se que a resistência ao arrancamento axial dos modelos cravados em solo
não fluidizado foi superior a resistência ao arrancamento dos modelos instalados em solo
fluidizado. Após a fluidização, a areia apresentou mesma densidade relativa final, próxima do
seu estado crítico (Dr ? 30%), independente da densidade relativa inicial (Dr = 50 e 90%) de
compactação.
A resistência lateral última axial à tração (Qf) das estacas mostrou-se maior quanto
maior a densidade relativa do solo (Dr), o comprimento cravado (L) e o diâmetro (de) da
estaca. O coeficiente de empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) apresentou-se menor quanto maior a
tensão efetiva vertical e quanto menor a densidade relativa da areia.
O solo não fluidizado apresentou o mesmo valor de resistência nos ensaios realizados
imediatamente e 24 horas após a cravação. Esta constatação refletiu os baixos níveis de
tensões de confinamento, onde os efeitos de setup em laboratório não são acentuados, pois a
dissipação das poropressões ocorre rapidamente e o efeito de quebra dos grãos (crushing) é
minimizado.
O solo fluidizado apresentou ganho de capacidade de carga com tempo de 24 horas
após a instalação (efeito de setup). O processo de ganho de resistência foi relacionado com a
dissipação das poropressões geradas pelo jateamento e o rearranjo/reacomodação dos grãos na
cavidade perturbada/erodida no entorno do fuste da estaca após o término da fluidização.
Tanto os resultados de instalação por fluidização, quanto os resultados de capacidade
de carga não apresentaram influência dos efeitos de fronteira, ou seja, relação entre as
dimensões do tanque e dimensões do modelo de estaca (D/de), como também os efeitos de
escala relacionados aos diferentes diâmetros de estacas e o diâmetro do grão de areia (de/d50)
não foram observados e identificados nos ensaios.
Os resultados dos ensaios desta pesquisa forneceram uma base consistente de dados,
dentro do intervalo de escalas trabalhadas. Tais resultados auxiliam no entendimento da
influência de diferentes parâmetros na instalação e no arrancamento de estacas em solo
fluidizado e não fluidizado. Ainda assim, os parâmetros de instalação e de arrancamento
obtidos devem ser considerados preliminares, sendo que estudos em modelos maiores
(emprego de menores fatores de escala de comprimento ?L) e tensões de confinamento mais
elevadas são necessários para melhor avaliá-los, antes do emprego em projetos de engenharia
offshore.
155 Capítulo 6 – Conclusões
Instalação e Capacidade de Carga Axial de Estacas Modelo Fluidizadas em Solos Arenosos
6.4 Sugestões para pesquisas futuras
Para trabalhos futuros de fluidização em solos arenosos, as sugestões são:
? Instalação de modelos com variação da vazão e velocidade de jateamento dentro do
mesmo ensaio de instalação (multi estágios);
? Aplicação inicial da vazão e velocidade de jateamento e leitura de suas variações
durante a instalação dos modelos;
? Aplicação de velocidade constante de instalação por fluidização (controle de
cravação);
? Execução de provas de carga à tração axial com controle de deslocamentos;
? Utilização de estacas com diferente rugosidade superficial;
? Utilização de outras granulometrias para areia uniforme;
? Utilização de pluviometria para preenchimento do tanque de ensaios;
? Aumento das tensões de confinamento;
? Aumento dos modelos (emprego de um menor fator escala de comprimento ?L) para
ensaios de estacas em laboratório;
? Aplicação técnica DIC (Digital Image Correlation) para ensaios na face do tanque,
visando o aprofundamento no conhecimento sobre os mecanismos, comportamento e
geometria da zona fluidizada;
? Utilização de sensores de pressão dentro da amostra de solo posicionados em
diferentes profundidades e distâncias do fuste das estacas;
? Estudo do fluxo radial entre as zonas fluidizada e não fluidizada;
? Análise do equilíbrio de forças atuantes no modelo de estaca durante o processo de
instalação por fluidização do solo;
? Execução de testes in situ em modelos.

1. Introduction
According to White & Bolton (2004), the mechanisms governing the behavior of displacement piles in sand
are not well understood. The axial capacity of displacement piles in sand is arguably the subject of greatest
uncertainty in geotechnical engineering. The literature on estimation of the uplift load capacity of piles is
limited (e.g. Vesic, 1967, 1970; Sowa, 1970; Meyerhof, 1973; Das & Seeley, 1975; Das et al., 1976, 1977;
Das, 1983; Levacher & Sieffert, 1984; Rao & Venkatesh, 1985; Chattopadhyay & Pise, 1986; Alawneh et al.,
1999; Gavin & Lehane, 2003; Shanker et al., 2007; Loukidis & Salgado, 2008; Basu & Salgado, 2012).
Therefore, the experimental methodology that has been adopted at Bowen Laboratory to study the sand
soil displacement field around the pile penetration and pullout on sand sample is by axisymmetric
boundary conditions using a half-circular model and a transparent observation window. The methodology
is based on the DIC (Digital Image Correlation) technique. The digital image correlation (DIC) technique is a
non-contact optical method employed in experimental mechanics to obtain full-field surface displacements
of a specimen during a loading event.
The basic principle of DIC is that the area of interest in the reference image is divided into a virtual grid.
The spacing of the grid defines the measurement resolution. The displacement calculations are made at
each node of the grid by tracking the same points (pixels) from the reference image to that in the
deformed image. The displacement vector of a subset is obtained from the difference between the
coordinates of the centers of the subset in the original configuration and the corresponding subset in the
deformed configuration as determined using a peak correlation algorithm (e.g. Cintron, 2008).
The digital image correlation requires computer software (VIC-2D) and an appropriate digital camera. To
get accurate measurements with this technique it is important to consider some variables (e.g. Cintron,
2008). Various parametric experiments were performed for assessing the accuracy of DIC correlation
algorithms, and key parameters influencing the accuracy of DIC analysis results were identified and they
were optimized, being the effect of refraction, lens distortion, illumination, particle disappearance from
view and glass scratching. Arshad et al. (2014) built the test chamber at Bowen Laboratory and took care of
the equipments setup, optimization of the parameters that influence the DIC analysis, cameras and
softwares.
Studies of White & Bolton (2003, 2004), Cintron (2008) and Arshad et al. (2014) provide guidance on the
calculation of data on the values of three single piles tested by digital image correlation DIC.
White & Bolton (2004) used digital images to measure soil displacement around the pile during monotonic
jacking into silica and carbonate sands. They conducted a series of plane strain calibration chamber tests in
order to quantify the penetration mechanism around the pile tip, and the response of the interface layer
adjacent to the shaft during further penetration. It was found the displacement and strain paths are
relatively independent of soil type.
According Arshad et al. (2014), the results of DIC analyses and measured cone resistance suggest that the
soil displacement around an advancing cone depends on the density and crushability of the sand, as well as
the depth of penetration. The displacements obtained from the DIC technique are, in general, close
estimates of the displacements that would be observed in the real problem.

2. Materials and equipments
The silica sand used in the tests presented sub-angular grain shape, particle size (d50) of 0.65 mm, specific
density (Gs) of 2.65, and maximum (emax) and minimum (emin) voids ratio of 0.853 and 0.537, respectively.
The sand named Ohio Gold Frac presented critical angle (?cv) of 36.4° and coefficient of uniformity (Cu)
equal to 1.37 and silicon dioxide (SiO2) = 99.7% (Arshad et al., 2014). The sand (Figure 2.1) was artificially
colored in order to facilitate the DIC test, once it is indispensable to get a good speckle pattern in order to
have success of measurements with VIC-2D (e.g. Cintron, 2008).The speckle pattern can be naturally
occurring or can be applied as in this study.
Figure 2.1. Sand
The pile used in this tests presented diameter of 31.75 mm, been a half-circular rod section with 915 mm
long, and a half-section conical tip with a 60° apex angle attached. The material of the pile was brass with
smooth surface. The frictional angle between the pile and the sand (?) was adopted equal to 0.65?cv or
23.66°.
The interface friction angle ? is expressed in terms of the critical state friction angle (?cv = 36.4 o ) for the
fine sand (e.g. Salgado, 2005, 2008; Velloso & Lopes, 2010; Basu et al., 2011; Basu & Salgado, 2012). This
assumption is justified by the very large vertical shear strains developed near the pile shaft at ultimate load
levels, expressed in terms of the constant-volume (or critical-state) friction angle (e.g. Lehane et al., 1993;
Jardine & Chow, 1996; Jardine et al., 1992, 1998; Alawneh et al., 1999; Loukidis & Salgado, 2008). The
interface friction angle is also a function of the interface material and its roughness (e.g. Potoyndy, 1961;
Kulhawy et al., 1983 Fioravante, 2002; Colombi, 2005; Lehane et al., 2005, 2012) and the pile type (Yang et
al., 2010). Kishida & Uesugi (1987) and Lehane et al. (2012) reported that sand interface shearing angles
are controlled by the ratio of the interface roughness R to the median grain size d50, up to the limit ? = ?cv.
The value adopted for ? is comparable to values proposed by Potts & Martins (1982), Lehane et al. (1993),
Alawneh et al. (1999, 2003), Paik & Salgado (2003), Patra & Pise (2003), Shanker (2006); Shanker et al.
(2007), Salgado (2008), Shelke & Mishra (2010), Yang et al. (2010) as well as with recommendations by the
American Petroleum Institute code of practice (API RP 2A, 1991).

The half-circular steel chamber was used in the present research with three observation windows, which
allowed imaging of the half-circular pile and the surrounding soil during the installation and pullout tests.
The tank presented a diameter of 1680 mm and a height of 1200 mm.
The size of the half-circular calibration chamber and half-circular pile were chosen in order to minimize
boundary and scale effects and the sand particle size was chosen in order to allow the analyses from the
images taken using the DIC (Digital Image Correlation) technique. The ratio between the tank and the pile
diameter (D/de) was 52.91 and the ratio between the pile and the sand (de/d50) was 48.84.
The jacking system (with 50 kN capacity) consisted of two screw jacks with a dedicated motor controller
was used to perform the pile tests at a constant displacement rate, range from 0 to 100 = 0 to 0.69 mm/s.
Two velocities were applied during the push and pull out tests, being 20 (0.12 mm/s) and 100 (0.69 mm/s).
The instrumentation sensors consisted for: i) two pressure sensors (Figure 2.2a), positioned on the sand
next to the pile shaft in two different depths (top and center of the sample, around 55 and 380 mm from
surface). The capacity of the top and tip pressure sensor was 200 kPa and 1 MPa, respectively. ii) three load
cells, one positioned on the bottom of the tank (Figure 2.2b) and two positioned on the pile, been
nominated the top (Figure 2.2c) and tip (Figure 2.2d) load cells with capacity of 20 kN and 10 kN,
respectively. iii) one linear position sensor/potentiometer (Figure 2.2e) to measure the displacement of the
pile with range of 640 mm.
Base boundary effects were monitored during testing by the tank load cell installed in the sample at the
base of the chamber along the pile penetration path. Lateral boundary effects were monitored by the two
miniature pressure transducers installed at two mid-height into the sample.

3. Laboratory procedures
? The procedure to fill the tank followed activities described below:
A new clear, annealed glass sheet (Figure 3.1a) was fixed behind the three windows (Figure 3.1b) every
test, using three different types of tapes (masking tape, duct tape and Packaging tape). The sand sample
was prepared by air pluviation using a large pluviator (# 9.95 mm) with a sieve (# 3.2 mm) attached (Figure
3.1c) in order to obtain a uniform dense sand (DR=90%). Without the sieve would obtain medium sand. The
amount of sand necessary to fulfill the tank was positioned and stored in six bags (Figure 3.1d) beside the

The axial capacity (Qf) of the pile during the pullout was 2425.4 N, 1819.1 N and 2615.8 N and the total
displacement (w) at the break (fail) was equal to 7.1 mm, 6.6 mm and 7.2 mm, respectively for first, second
and third test. The first test presented greater axial capacity than second test because of its suffered more
and short strokes during the jacking at the installation process (e.g Foray et al., 2010; Basu et al., 2011). As
it was expected, the third pullout test presented greater axial capacity over all, since during the pile
installation it’s suffered hammer blows and also had two rest periods (setup).
Lim & Lehane (2014) showed from their laboratory tension load tests results, a clear and consistent trend
for driven piles to have larger shaft capacities than monotonically jacked piles. Although the experiments
accomplished by the authors showed that rate of capacity gain with time for the driven piles is generally
higher than that of the jacked piles, this trend is less obvious than seen in the field by Lim (2013), who
found much higher relative increases in capacity with time for the driven piles. The average ultimate shaft
frictions mobilized by buried piles at the laboratory before and after rested was similar. The observed
change was clearly negligible compared to changes observed for the displacement piles (driven and
jacked), indicating that setup must be due to the disturbance induced during pile installation in their
studies.
According to York et al. (1994); Tan et al. (2004); Yan & Yuen (2010) and Steward & Wang (2011), in
geotechnical engineering practice, the increase of pile capacity after installation is known as pile setup. Pile
setup is the phenomenon of the increase of pile capacity over time (Axelsson, 1998; Axelsson & Westin,
2000; Foray et al., 2010 and Lim & Lehane, 2014), during and after the dissipation of pore pressure and the
stabilization of lateral earth pressure.
This phenomenon is definitely favorable to engineering designs, such as in many important practical
implications concerning testing methods, the programming of foundation construction, and the
reassessment of existing driven pile capacities. Increase in pile capacity after initial driving has been well
observed in clays and sands over decades. Chow et al. (1998) complement that much uncertainty
surrounds the factors responsible for these changes and these changes in the stress regimes created during
pile driving are probably responsible for the observed setup.

However, recent evidence (e.g. Yamamuro et al., 1996; Lade, 2007; Lade et al., 1997, 2009, 2010; Lade &
Karimpour, 2010; Karimpour & Lade, 2010; Yang et al., 2010; Lim & Lehane,2014) appears to show that
setup in sand is closely related to particle crushing. When the stresses on soil particles exceed their
strengths, particle breakage occurs. Very little crushing occurs at low confining pressures, while
experiments show that considerable crushing occurs at higher confining pressures where the time effects
are also pronounced. The amount of crushing relates to the amount of energy input to the soil. Thus, time
effects are related to energy input and crushing.
Because of the explanation above it were included different types of installation and rest time in the tests.
However, these effects could not be observed clearly, since all three tests presented similar behavior and
results.

7. Conclusion
The results presented in this report provide detailed experimental evidence of the mechanisms of a
displacement pile during axial uplift request. The digital image correlation DIC software Vic-2D is able to
provide logical and useful displacement and strain maps to show the behavior of the granular soil during
the deformation process. The system is capable to detect the areas with higher strains inside the area of
interest. The acquired knowledge was of great value during the student passage at Purdue University and
will be disseminated at Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul – geotechnical engineering program, in
order to add the technique in their researches.

On the response of fluidized piles from laboratory model tests in granular soils
F. Schnaid?, L. Passini, F. Stracke and S. Mezzomo Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil
Abstract. Design guidelines of foundation anchors and piles embedded in fluidized sand comprises understanding of installation processes, defining constitutive parameters and establishing analysis techniques. These fundamental aspects have been inves- tigated by a series of laboratory model tests designed to evaluate the mechanism taking place during pile installation through the influence of downwardly-directed vertical water jets in the geometry of fluidized cavities in saturated sands. Measurements indicate fluidization geometry to be controlled by combined effects of jet velocity and the ratio of particle and jet diameters which can be conveniently expressed by the Froude number of particles. Characteristics of the fluidized zone geometry prior and after fluidization indicate considerable reduction of relative density of fluidized samples. Limit equilibrium analysis using geotechnical parameters approaching critical state provided indicative horizontal stress levels to estimate the uplift skin friction of model steel piles.
Keywords: Fluidization, sands, piles
1. Introduction
Fluidization is defined as the suspension of particles due to the action of an upward fluid flow. General principles and mechanisms of fluidization in granular soils have been comprehensively analysed and have given rise to a number of applications in the field of channelling [23, 32, 33], erosion [1], removal of sediments and remediation of contaminants (e.g. [3, 6, 22, 24]). Despite being a common feature in several disciplines, the application of fluidization processes to foundation engineering is not well understood and possible applications have not been fully explored. Although empirical approaches provide valuable insights for onshore, nearshore and offshore foundations (e.g. [4, 9, 11]), there is no standardized design methodology. Under current configurations, there is scope to provide recommendations to optimise the jetting performance by verifying some of the essential features of the fluidization process that occurs as a jet is lowered into a granular medium. Implications of the fluidization process to piles analysis and design are discussed on the light of critical state soil mechanics.
2. Materials and methods
Fluidization, piezocone and load tests were carried out in rectangular acrylic chambers with internal dimensions of 478 mm × 278 mm × 320 mm and 450 mm × 450 mm × 1100 mm high (Fig. 1a, c). Siliceous sand specimen prepared using the moist tamping method were carefully inundated by water percolating upwards until it reaches a water constant head of 5 cm above the soil surface. It is then maintained constant throughout the test to ensure that the flow rate and therefore the jet velocity are constant.

To start the test, a metal tube is positioned vertically on the soil surface, being lowered in increments during the jetting stage. Carbon steel metal tubes have been used with internal diameters ranging from 3.85 mm to 12 mm (Fig. 1d). A downwardly-directed vertical water jet velocity is applied through the tubes and at the end of each stage, after completion of the fluidization process, the tube is repositioned in increasing depths within the chamber. A supporting structure equipped with a ball-screw allowed the gradual displacement of the tubes at any location below the sand surface in a precise upright position (Fig. 1b). The descent of the tubes is conducted in 20 mm increments along the depth.
A schematic representation of the experimental setup is presented in Fig. 2. The hydraulic circuit consists on a PVC pipeline where the water from a 500 litter’s reservoir flows driven by a centrifugal pump. The pump motor is connected to a frequency inverter, which regulates the rotation speed of the pump and thus the flow rate, measured by a rotameter. The insertion tubes are the final part of the circuit. The water produces a jet emanating from the tubes that fluidizes the soil zone when inserted inside the sand.
The tubes installed into the soil were later used as prototype piles to perform load tests using the steel casing attached to the chamber as a reaction frame. A seating load varying from 1 to 7 N (corresponding to the actual weight of the pile) was applied prior to zeroing the dial gauges and additional load was then applied in small increments ranging from 10 to 15 percent of the design load and maintained for a few minutes (necessary for complete stabilization of displacements).
Two sands have been tested, corresponding to the fine and coarse particle size distribution shown in Fig. 3. The fine sand comes from a natural deposit located in Brazil (Osorio Sand), while the coarse sand is a material selected

For tests carried out in the present study, for each depth, the tube was held in a fixed position and measurements of the fluidized zone geometry were recorded. After completion of each stage, the tube was lowered and the procedure repeated. Experiments were conducted with the jet positioned in the centre of the tank and adjacent to the tank wall for observation purposes. In this last case, the geometric information was obtained by direct observation through the walls of the acrylic tank covered with a plastic film to allow tracing of fluidized contours of the cavity. In addition experiments have been photographed and filmed.
For any given sand, three groups of tests have been carried out as outlined below.
a) Constant flow rate (Qo) with variations in the injection diameter (dj ) and jet velocity (Uo) b) Constant jet velocity (Uo) with variations in the injection diameter (dj ) and flow rate (Qo) c) Constant injection diameter (dj ) with variations in jet velocity (Uo) and flow rate (Qo)
Controlled variables are the injection diameter (dj ), that is the same of the internal pile diameter (di), external pile diameter (de), pile length inside sand specimen (L), sand physical properties, water height above the soil (hw) and the dimensions of the tank. Measured parameters are the flow rate (Qo), temperature of the water and the geometry of the steady state fluidized zone which is all represented in Fig. 4. A series of 63 tests in lateral position inside the tank was carried out to evaluate the influence of flow rate in the range of 0.70 and 6.80 L/min and jet velocity in the range 0.13 to 4.29 m/s, as summarized in Table 2. Direct observation of the measured steady state geometries indicates that, for a given sand and constant input parameters, the increase in flow rate leads to increasing dH and a values. For a given flow, the diameter of the fluidized zone reduces with increasing average particle diameter (D50 or dp). As for the jet velocity, for a given sand and flow rate, the larger the diameter of the jet (dj ) the lower the radii of the fluidized zone at the jet tip dH and the jet penetration depth a. Consequently, as the jet velocity increases the diameter of the fluidized zone and the jet penetration depth also increase. The soil movement due to turbulent flow under high jet velocities extended up to 20 pile diameters from the side of the prototype piles and up to 30 diameters below the pile tip. The geometry of the fluidized zone reported here is representative of tubes fixed vertically and lowered into the ground in increments during the jet stage: this condition differs from piles lowered into the ground by the own self-weight during fluidization (to be addressed in a separate publication).

5. Sand density
Once the prediction of steady state fluidized zone geometry from system variables is completed, the additional requirement for foundation design is the density of the fluidized area after completion of fluidized cycle. During fluidization, the granular particles are subjected to an upward fluid flow which creates a drag force sufficient to support the weight of the particles [16]. Once the jet is halted, viscous and kinetic energy is lost, a general slope failure occurs and closures the fluidized bed. Consequently, the density of the fluidized area prior and after fluidization is expected to change.
Cone penetrometer test (CPT) characterization of the two sands used in these tests allowed density to be estimated prior and after fluidization. CPT results are presented in terms of the variation of tip cone resistance qc with depth measured with a 8 mm diameter minicone (0.5 cm2 cross section area) for tests carried out in fine and coarse, fluidized and non-fluidized sand (Fig. 9). In fine sand, the qc values for both medium and dense samples increase linearly with depth. The relative density (Dr) of the undisturbed denser sand is of about 90%, corresponding to qc = 680 kPa at the mid-height of sample in the centre of the tank, and reduces to qc = 250 kPa for a medium density of 50%. After fluidization the cone resistance reduces to an average value of about qc = 125 kPa for both samples (dense and medium initial densities), which corresponds to fluidizeds and densities of about 30%.
Similar results have been obtained for coarse sand, as indicated by the measurements of cone resistance qc for medium dense samples (Fig. 9b). The coarse sand produces profiles with many small sharp peaks and troughs due to the large size of grains in respect to the diameter of the cone. The initial measured relative density of 50%

6. Implications to design
The shaft friction developed on displacement piles is related to the degree of soil displacement imparted during pile installation. Factors to be considered in the development of shaft friction prediction methods are radial effective stress at failure, interface friction angle between the soil and pile, type and number of cycles imposed during drivability, mode of loading, among others (e.g. [5, 19, 25, 26]). Because of the shortage of high quality measurements of shaft friction on tension jacked steel piles and the lack of consistent data on fluidization piles, the analysis of the potential implications of the fluidization process to foundation design is investigated in the present work by a series of tension load tests carried out in fine sands.

The work comprises 90 tests in hydraulic displacement piles (jacked piles), immediately and 24 hours after pile driven, and 36 tests in fluidized piles, by suspended tubes and piles lowered into the ground by the own self-weight during fluidization, 24 hours after pile installation, both in the center position inside the tank. The testing programme described in Table 3 corresponds to tests performed in fine sand with initial sand density of 50% and 90%. Loads were applied in stages and increased up to failure, as illustrated by the typical results of load-displacement curves shown in Fig. 10. Being load control, tests provide reliable and accurate measurements of maximum loads but do not allow brittle post-peak behavior to be detected, particularly for piles in denser sand. The uplift displacement-to- diameter ratios at failure are of the order of 0.01% and at this stage the maximum load characterizes the pile shaft uplift capacity, Qf .
A possible reason for foundations submitted to tensile loading presenting displacements that are smaller than those with the same compressive load is that shear strains under uplift loading are more pronounced than volumetric strains in contributing to displacements. In the case of fine sand, the combination of pile roughness (smooth pile) and the fine grain size produces a thin shear band at the soil-pile interface, thus yielding to very small displacements to reach failure conditions. Coarse sand, specially for dilative interface, would exhibit distinct pile response.
In this set of experiments it has been observed that, for each relative density, values of Qf measured immediately and 24 hours after pile installation in non-fluidized soil remained unchanged, as expected, since the material has high permeability and fast dissipation of initial excess pore pressures. The impact of the fluidization process on overall shaft capacity is considerable, reflecting the changes in sand density (Dr). In addition, given to the laws of similarity, values of Qf are shown to be dependent on pile diameter (de) and length (L) and independent from flow rate (Qo), as demonstrated in Fig. 11 (a, b and c).

One simplifying assumption in the interpretation of these model pile tests is to assume ?f constant over the pile shaft for both fluidized and non-fluidized piles. The effective vertical stress corresponds to the overburden stress, despite the fact that in sand unit shaft resistance does not necessarily increase linearly with depth (e.g. [15, 31]).
For the fine sand, the interface friction angle ? is assumed to be the same as the critical state friction angle (?cv = 26.6
? ), as obtained from triaxial and ring shear tests conducted by Consoli et al. [7]. The assumption of
? = ?cv is justified by the very large vertical shear strains developed near the pile shaft at ultimate load levels, expressed in terms of the constant-volume (or critical-state) friction angle (e.g. [17, 18]). It is supported by direct interface shear tests [14, 17] and in close agreement to recommendations from by the American Petroleum Institute code of practice [2].
Within these assumptions, the average coefficient of lateral earth pressure Ks for each test is calculated using equation 6 (Fig. 12a, b and c) for fluidized and non-fluidized fine sand. Ks values at full mobilisation of limit shaft resistance are shown to increase with increasing sand relative density and decrease with increasing initial effective overburden stress. At higher stresses (i.e. longer piles) Ks values become relatively constant, reaching minimum of 0.15, 0.30 and 0.50 for fluidized, non-fluidized Dr = 50% and non-fluidized Dr = 90% sand specimens, respectively. These measured values of Ks are slightly lower than early reported data and yield Ks/K0 ratios of the order of 1.0 and 2.0 for non-fluidized sand at 50% e 90% respectively (e.g. [28]). Maximum Ks values order of 1.5 in non-fluidized sand (Ks/K0 ?4.5) and have been obtained and very low confining stresses.
Although grain size effects become negligible for de/d50 larger than 100 to 200 [8, 10], these calculated values should be considered as preliminary indications of Ks and further validation in larger model scales is necessary before their use in engineering design.

7. Conclusions
This paper reports results from small scale laboratory model tests carried out to investigate the mechanisms of pile installation in fluidized sands. Considering that the research aims at supporting the prediction the geometry and density of fluidized cavities for future use in foundation design, attention has been given to the analysis of the fluidization jet penetration depth and fluidization radii at the pile tip. These variables are shown to be controlled by combined effects of jet velocity and the ratio of particle and jet diameter, being conveniently expressed by the Froude number of particles. Once the prediction of fluidized zone geometry from system variables was completed, the additional requirement was referred to the density of the fluidized sand bed prior and after fluidization. Despite the initial density, the sand approaches the same low density after fluidization which is a state close to critical state soil conditions. Variation in density impacts the prediction of pile bearing capacity: the shaft tensile capacity of jacked piles is shown to reduce considerably when compared to the same pile installed in the ground by fluidization.

ABSTRACT: The torpedo pile is an anchoring offshore structure system widely used in Brazil in deep waters. The installation procedure consists in the release of the torpedo from a high position from the sea bottom to allow the device to reach its terminal velocity. Penetration depth is a function of kinetic energy, weight and geometry of the torpedo, seabed shear resistance and penetration angle. Since penetration in sand may not be sufficient to provide the necessary anchor bearing capacity, an alternative procedure is to combine the free-fall energy to soil fluidization. This alternative is evaluated in this paper by considering the use of circular, single and continuous vertical jets from the tip of model torpedo piles. Laboratory tests were performed in a reduced model using tubes to simulate torpedo without wings, following the law of similarity of Froude number. Pile penetration is shown to be a function of the pile weight, flow rate, jet velocity and relative density of sand bed.
KEYWORDS: Torpedo Piles, Fluidization, Fine Sand.
1 INTRODUCTION
The oil industry has emerged as a major source of accelerating the development of Brazil, both economically and technologically, for example, with the oil exploration in waters and in deeper and deeper layers. The recent discovery by Petrobras of the existence of oil in the pre-salt region, in the basins of southern and southeastern Brazil, determined the offshore exploitation frontier to move fast to water depths and requiring development of new technologies related to the installation and fixing of offshore structures. The installation costs increase as the water depth increases. The high number of floating production and drilling units may congest of the sea bottom due to the high number of risers and mooring lines employed. In order to minimize this problem, taut leg mooring systems are commonly employed by the offshore oil industry, e.g. Kunitaki (2006) and Costa (2008). The torpedo anchor (Figure 1) developed by Petrobras has proven to be an outstanding
alternative for deep water, high load applied and low ground capacity in taut leg mooring systems, e.g. Medeiros (2002) and Henriques Jr. et al., (2010). This anchor requests simple installation equipment with low cost. Torpedo piles are released from a designated height above the seafloor and penetrate to a target depth in the seabed by the kinetic energy obtained through free fall and through the own weight of the anchor, e.g. O’Loughlin, et al., (2004), Silva (2008), and Lavieri (2011). Brazilian offshore fields are majority composed by clayey seabed, where the torpedo pile reaches a satisfactory depth penetration, but some of them are sandy and the anchor cannot drill enough. Therefore, fluidization can be used to help the anchor installation using vertical jets from the tip of the torpedo. Fluidization is the suspension of soil particles due to the action of an upward flow, which creates a force sufficient to support the actual weight of the particles drag (Figure 2), according to Leva (1959). The principles and mechanisms of fluidization sandy soils using
suspended tubes have been studied and used in the navigation channel engineering, environmental engineering and the study of erosion caused by the impact of the water jet on the bed, e.g. Westrich & Kobus (1973), Rajaratnam & Beltaos (1977), Rajaratnam (1982), Weisman et al., (1982, 1988), Weisman & Lennon (1994), Aderibigbe & Rajaratnam (1996) and Niven (1998).
Figure 1. Petrobras torpedo anchor, after Araujo et al. (2004).
Figure. 2. Schematic representation of the fluidization using suspended tubes, after Niven (1998).
Fluidization is also used in onshore and nearshore foundation engineering, as well as in systems and operations offshore. Despite the fact that it is being extensively used in foundation engineering, relatively little information is available regarding the process fluidization, e.g. Shestopal (1959), Tsinker (1972, 1977, and 1988), Gabr, et. al. (2007), Zeilinger (2009) and Bhasi et. al. (2010), and empirical approaches are often used in design. Recent studies on the mechanisms and parameters involved in the fluidization process have been presented by Mezzomo (2009),
Stracke (2012), Alsaydalani & Clayton (2013) and Schnaid et. al. (2004). The present paper extends these early views by exploring the installation mechanisms of torpedo piles in granular soils.

Rectangular acrylic chambers with internal dimensions of 450 mm x 450 mm x 1100 mm high and wall thickness of 15 mm were used in the tests. Siliceous sand specimen prepared using the moist tamping method to simulate the seabed at relative densities of 50% and 90% were carefully inundated by water percolating upwards, with constant flow rate of 0.7 L/min, until it reaches a water constant head of 50 mm above the soil surface. It is then maintained constant throughout the test to ensure that the flow rate and therefore the jet
velocity are constant. Carbon steel metal tubes (smooth surface) have been used to simulate de torpedo piles (without wings) with internal diameter (di) of 11.6 mm, and external diameters (de) of 16.2 mm. No boundary effects were observed between the results. The minimum distance between the pile and the tank walls exceeded 25de. The radial flow percolates through the sand and may occasionally reach the boundaries, flowing upwards and out the tank, without affecting the actual geometry and depth of the fluidized sand. A schematic representation of the experimental setup is presented in Figure 4. The hydraulic circuit consists on a PVC pipeline where the water from a 500 litter’s reservoir flows driven by a centrifugal pump. The pump motor is connected to a frequency inverter, which regulates the rotation speed of the pump and thus the flow rate, measured by a low flow sensor with a digital transmitter/totalizer also connected to the frequency inverter encoded PID. The insertion tubes are the final part of the circuit. The water produces a jet emanating from the tubes that fluidizes the soil zone when inserted inside the sand.

The models installed in non-fluidized soil were also positioned vertically on the soil surface and then released. Both kinds of tests were in the center position inside the tank. The variables controlled were the internal diameter (di), which is the same of the injection diameter (dj), external pile diameter (de), mass in air of the test models (m), physical properties of the sand (Dr), water height above the soil (hw) and the dimensions of the tank. The measured parameters were the flow rate (Qo), jet velocity (Uo), pile length inside sand specimen (L) and installation time (t) from tests carried out in the center position of the tank.
2.2 Similarity
The study of the behavior of offshore foundations in scale models is necessary due to the difficulties of their realization in full-scale, which demand repetition of tests, specialized companies, appropriate area and equipment with high cost. Thus, model scales are convenient. Model tests were performed at scale of 1:67, being the modeling ratio N, established according the principles of similitude, conveniently expressed by the Froude number (Fr=U/(gD)
0.5) . This is a dimensionless
number defined as the ratio of a characteristic velocity to a gravitational wave velocity. It may equivalently be defined as the ratio of a body's inertia to gravitational forces. This modeling is a testing methodology in which in-situ stress conditions are not replicated at a reduced scale. As such, the (mechanical) behavior of a prototype soil mass under Earth’s gravity (g) is not replicated in a small-scale, and the scaling factor for gravity g is 1. The length scale was obtained by using the ratio between the external diameter of the model and prototype. The dimensions of the prototype torpedo piles adopted were 1.07 m external diameter, 17 m length and masses of 66 and 120 tones, representative of anchor used by Petrobras, according to Medeiros Jr., (2002), Kunitaki (2006), Costa (2008), Silva et al. 2.3 Fluidization Parameters
Fluidization velocity is a key parameter in the analysis, because at low velocities the material does not fluidized and at very high velocity the solid material is carried along with the fluid out of the bed (Leva, 1959; Wen & Yu, 1966; Niven, 1998). The minimum fluidization velocity (Umf) of the fine sandy bed, being 4.21x10
-4 m/s, was overcome, since this value is
much lower than the water jet velocities (Uo) imposed in the tests. Therefore, the particles of the sand were dragged out of the fluidized zone and the models were installed.
Three parameters form dimensionless groups and are important in fluidized soil: Froude number of particles (Frp), Reynolds number of particles (Rep) and Reynolds number of the jet (Rej), as Westrich & Kokus (1973), Rajaratnam & Beltaos (1977), Rajaratnam (1982), Mih & Kabir (1983), Aderibigbe & Rajaratnam (1996), Niven (1998), Mezzomo (2009) and Stracke (2012). The Froude number of particles (Frp) is between 1.89 and 4.33, the Reynolds number of particles (Rep) goes from 22.74 to 51.99 and the Reynolds number of the jet (Rej) from 1274.57 to 2913.29. 3 RESULTS
3.1 Installation without Fluidization
Installation of piles at their own weight (without drop height and without fluidization) was performed at early testing stage. The tubes were
manually released with the tip being in contact with the surface prepared soil in relative densities of 50% and 90%. Results of 22 tests, being 9 tests at 50% density and 13 tests 90% density showed that pile penetration increases with pile weight in air and reduces with increasing the relative density (Figure 6).
Figure 6. Pile penetration by own weight in air without fluidization at Dr=50% and 90%.
3.2 Installation by Fluidization
Tests carried out by fluidization are presented in Figures 7 and 8, showing results from 46 tests, being 12 tests with pile air mass of 400g and 15 tests at 220g, both at relative density of 50%, and 19 tests with pile air mass of 220g, at relative density of 90%. Measured penetration by fluidization is compared to results obtained by driving piles at their own weight. As seen in the figures 7 and 8, the pile penetration increases with increasing pile air weight, flow rate and jet velocity, for the same relative density; and pile penetration reduces with increasing sand relative density, applying the same model weight, flow rates and jet velocities.
The model installation velocity (displacement versus time) was measured during the fluidization tests for each model weight in air, relative density and flow rate applied. Results of 51 tests, being 19 tests with pile air mass of 400g and 18 tests at 220g, both at relative density of 50%, and 14 tests with pile air mass of 220g, at relative density of 90%, are presented at Figure 9, 10 and 11.
Figure 7. Pile penetration versus flow rate applied at Dr=50% and 90%.
Figure 8. Pile penetration versus jet velocity applied at Dr=50% and 90%.
The thick lines at the Figures 9, 10 and 11
represent the average behavior for each combination of weight in air and flow rate applied during the installation process. The initial installation velocity is higher as higher is the flow rate imposed. All tests had similar penetration behavior.
All graphs indicate higher installation velocity at the beginning of each test and it goes decreasing until the model stops to penetrate. This behavior is the same of the torpedo piles installed by own weight through free fall above the seabed when it starts to penetrate into the ground, e.g. Kunitaki (2006), Fernandes et al., (2006), Amaral, 2008, O’Loughlin et al., (2004).

4 CONCLUSIONS
Results from laboratory model tests of fluidized anchor torpedo piles installed in granular soils are discussed in this paper. Pile penetration is shown to be a function of the pile weight, flow rate, jet velocity and relative density of samples.
As a general conclusion, the installation process of anchor systems in granular soils can be optimized without great effort and coasts by fluidization.

UPLIFT CAPACITY OF TORPEDO PILES INSTALLED BY SOIL FLUIDIZATION THROUGH VERTICAL JETS
Larissa de Brum Passini Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil, larissapassini@hotmail.com

ABSTRACT: Looking for an alternative method to aid the installation of anchors offshore in seabed, torpedo pile, an element of foundation already well-known in Brazil, is explored in this paper, in order to assess its ability to axial tensile load, since vertical water jets expelled from the tip of the torpedo allowed its penetration into sandy seabed by fluidization, using seawater. Laboratory tests were performed in a reduced model, using tubes to simulate torpedo without wings, following the law of similarity of Froude number. Pullout tests through load increments were performed on models in fluidized and non-fluidized sandy soil at two initial relative densities. The models installed by soil fluidization occurred by own weight (without drop height) and model installed in non-fluidized soils were inserted manually (monotonic jacking). Characteristics of the bed prior and after fluidization indicate considerable reduction of relative density of fluidized samples. Limit equilibrium analysis using geotechnical parameters approaching critical state provided indicative horizontal stress levels to estimate the uplift skin friction of model steel piles.
KEYWORDS: Torpedo Piles, Fine Sand, Uplift Capacity.
1 INTRODUCTION
A global trend for both the offshore oil and gas industry and the offshore renewable energy industry is going further to deep water where is located the highest energy potential. Thus, new challenges of development of technologies are requested in order to install, fix and operate offshore structures with costs at a reasonable level without compromising reliability of it. Petrobras developed the Torpedo anchor (Figure 1) for deep water, high loads applied and soil with low resistance (clayey seabed). The torpedo anchor is embedded into the seabed by free fall using its own weight as the driving energy. An alternative method for this anchor installation in sandy soil is through fluidization by vertical water jets (Figure 2). Fluidization is defined as the suspension of soil particles due to the action of an upward flow, which creates a force sufficient to support the actual weight of the particles drag, producing a fluidized bed.
Figure 1. Petrobras torpedo anchor, Araujo et al. (2004).
Figure 2. Fluidization of fine sand using suspended tubes, after Mezzomo (2009).
Fluidization has been studied in different areas of engineering, such as in erosion, navigation channel and environmental/ remediation using suspended tubes. Also, it is applied empirically in onshore and nearshore foundations engineering, as well as in systems and operations offshore. The torpedo pile shaft uplift capacity is important issue to be evaluated in order use the technology of installation through soil fluidization. Therefore, this paper presents experimental data obtained from of pullout tests in reduced scales of model anchor. This research has been developed as part of the project signed between Petrobras and Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS).

3 RESULTS
3.1 Pile Shaft Uplift Capacity
The present work investigates the shaft friction on tension on fluidization and non-fluidization piles by a series of tension load tests carried out in fine sands. These analyses are important for foundation design using fluidization process. A seating load corresponding to the actual weight of the pile was applied prior to zeroing the dial gauges and additional load was then applied in small increments and maintained for a few minutes (necessary for complete stabilization of displacements). Loads were applied in stages and increased up to failure, and only at this final loading stage, piles experienced large displacements, defining a maximum load that characterizes the pile shaft uplift capacity, Qf. From limit equilibrium analysis, shaft capacity of the tested piles is expressed as:

One simplifying assumption in the interpretation of these model pile tests is to assume ?f constant over the pile shaft for both fluidized and non-fluidized piles. The effective vertical stress corresponds to the overburden stress, despite the fact that in sand unit shaft resistance does not necessarily increase linearly with depth, according to Kerizel (1961) and Vésic (1967). Within these considerations, the average coefficient of lateral earth pressure Ks for each test is calculated using eq. 3, for fluidized and non-fluidized fine sand.
3.2 Pullout Tests in Non-Fluidized Soil.
Pullout test was done immediately and 24 hours after pile been installed in non-fluidized soil. The models were manually jacking in four predetermined depths: 100, 200, 360 and 500 mm. The outside diameters of the model piles (16.2 mm) was chosen so that they have L/D ratios comparable to some those for cylindrical piles in the field (for the model piles, L/D = 6.17 to 30.86).
The work comprises 35 tests, being 17 tests in soil at initial relative density of 50% and 18 tests in soil at initial relative density of 90% (Figure 7 and 8). It has been observed that, for each relative density, the values of Qf measured immediately and 24 hours after pile installation in non-fluidized soil remained unchanged, as expected, since the material has high permeability and fast dissipation of initial excess pore pressures.
Figure 7. Pile shaft uplift capacity (Qf) vs pile length inside sand specimen (L) in non-fluidized soil, with initial Dr=50% and 90%.
Figure 8. Coefficient of lateral earth pressure (Ks) vs pile length inside sand specimen (L) in non-fluidized soil, with initial Dr=50% and 90%.
Results from Ks values at full mobilization of limit shaft resistance are shown to increase with increasing sand relative density and decrease with increasing initial effective overburden stress (Figures 8), as reported by Loukidis, & Salgado (2008). At higher stresses (i.e. longer piles) Ks values become relatively constant, corresponding to 0.30 (Dr=50%) and 0.50 (Dr=90%) for non- fluidized sand specimens. Higher values of Ks corresponding to shallower depths (lower confining stresses).
3.3 Pullout Tests in Fluidized Soil.
Pullout test was done 24 hours after pile been installed through soil fluidization. The models were installed by soil fluidization associate with theirs own weight (without drop height), starting in contact with the bed surface.
The work comprises 16 tests (Figures 9 and 10), being 9 tests in soil at initial relative density of 50% and 7 tests in soil at initial relative density of 90%.
Figure 9. Pile shaft uplift capacity (Qf) vs pile length inside sand specimen (L) in fluidized soil, with initial Dr=50% and 90%.
Figure 10. Coefficient of lateral earth pressure (Ks) vs pile length inside sand specimen (L) in fluidized soil, with initial Dr=50% and 90%.
The impact of the fluidization process on overall shaft capacity is considerable, reflecting the changes in sand relative density. Despite the initial relative density, the sand approaches the same low density after fluidization which is a state close to critical state soil conditions. The relative density considered after fluidization is 30%, for purposes of calculating the coefficient of lateral earth pressure Ks. This conclusion from pullout tests is also in conformity with results of mini cone penetrometer tests (MCPT) executed in the same fluidized fine sand compacted at these two initial relative densities, by Mezzomo (2009). The author found values of relative density
between 10% and 40%, and he concludes that certainly the relative density was less than 30%.
Values of Qf are shown to be dependent on the length (L) and independent from flow rate (Qo) applied during the installation tests by soil fluidization. Also at higher stresses (i.e. longer piles) Ks values become relatively constant, around 0.10 to 0.15 for fluidized sand specimens. Testing at greater depths are being conducted in order to get more values and confirm the results of Ks. A typical shaft resistance versus displacements of tensile load tests is presented at Figure 11, using tubes with external diameter (de) of 16.2 mm and pile length inside sand specimen (L) around of 360 mm, in non- fluidized and fluidized soil at initial relative density of 50% and 90%. A possible reason for foundations submitted to tensile loading presenting displacements that are smaller than those with the same compressive load is that shear strains under uplift loading are more pronounced than volumetric strains in contributing to displacements. Furthermore, it was load control tests.
